name: peat moss production, horticultural use | peat moss | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/11371/documentation

This datasets represents the production of peat moss for horticultural use. ;Sphagnum peat moss, rated H1-H4 within the "Von Post" scale (H1 to H6), is younger and less decomposed than combustible peat. It has a high value on the horticultural market. On the contrary, peat intended for energy production has higher von Post grades, is older, darker peat, with higher C content. ;The reference flow is 1 m³ of dry peat moss in loose form (equivalent to not compressed). A density of 100 kg/m³ is considered for dry peat moss in loose form. All flows are calculated based on a weighted average of all Quebec sites covered by the data collection process. ;;Data quality indicators adjusted accordingly.;;The plastic packaging in which the peat moss is sold in compressed form is NOT included. Here are some information on the 4 most common bag sizes: ;-1.56 m³ compressed (3.11 m³ loose equivalent),;- 0.108 m³ compressed (0.215 m³ loose equivalent), ;- 0.0622 m³ (0.125 m³ loose equivalent), ;- 0.0793 m³ loose. ;At the use phase, an average amount of 0.556 kg of LDPE plastic packaging per m³ of dry loose peat moss should be sent to waste management.

Starts from the delivery on site of the material and energy inputs.

This activity ends with compressed and bagged peat moss, ready for shipping to distributors.
This dataset includes: the opening (construction of roads; drainage, removal and clearing of vegetation), annual operations (maintenance of ditches, site preparation, peat harvesting), and site closure (restoration) of the peat bog; the administrative buildings and their energy consumption; the transport from the bog to the conditioning plant and conditioning (including compressing and bagging) of the harvested sphagnum peat moss; and land use and land transformation.
This datasets excludes: the wood and vegetation cleared during the site opening since it is left on site without further treatment (its aerobic degradation is assumed to have no net emissions), however, the energy and machinery required for their management are accounted for; the tertiary packaging (pallets and wrap).
 
Plastic packaging is also excluded and should be added to the use phase (see General Comment for details).
category: B:Mining and quarrying/08:Other mining and quarrying/089:Mining and quarrying n.e.c./0892:Extraction of peat

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data from Quebec sites. Data quality indicators adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Data collected from Quebec sites were used to represent an average technology. For site opening and annual operations, the specific machinery used by each site are considered. For site closure, a weighted average of five technological options (dry restoration, wet restoration, reforestation, plantation of berries and natural regenaration) was calculated considering the operations of Canadian peat bogs in recent years.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
For each unit operation, a weighted average (based on production) was calculated for the sites for which the most detailed information was available. Depending on the operation, the data do not include the same data sources. 
For site closure operations, it was assumed that the distribution of management approaches, between natural regeneration, reforestation, rewetting, and ecological restoration, was the same for Quebec as for Canada since Quebec data were insufficiant and Canadian data were used.
Data quality indicators adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Information were collected by questionnaires in 2006 and 2010  from five companies operating in Quebec. Data concerning annual operations (maintenance of ditches, site preparation, peat harvesting) as well as administrative buildings, transport and conditioning operations were provided in 2006, and judged applicable for 2010 by the data providers. 
Data for peat bog opening, preparation and closure were updated in 2010.

exchanges.description: Volume equivalent loose. Packed in plastic bag. Fossil carbon content of plastic packaging not included in peat moss product flow properties, preventing carbon inputs and outputs form balancing out.

flow.name: peat moss

exchanges.description: Dry mass. Includes loss (mineralization to CO2 and CH4) during peat bog operation (33%) and use at site closure (0.04%, for dry restoration only). Peat is assumed to be lost before and after harvesting (due to overheating while stacked in field). From 22 to 44% of harvested volume is lost, assuming 350E3 t of peat per km² are extracted from a peat bog (Cleary 2005, p.458).
